Authors:
Daniela Aguiar Souza, Marcos Faria, Richard Alan Humber,
Rogerio Biaggioni Lopes
Title:
Assessment of the Brazilian diversity of fungi in the
Beauveria bassiana species complex
Keywords:
Ascomycota, Cordycipitaceae, genetic diversity, phylogeny,
insect fungi, biocontrol
Abstract:
We combined matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization
time-of-flight mass spectrometry (MALDI-TOF MS) along sequencing of the
nuclear intergenic region Bloc in order to assess the diversity of
Brazilian species within the anamorphic complex Beauveria bassiana. A
total of 121 strains housed in a government-owned culture and isolated
from a range of hosts/substrates over a reasonably long time span
(1981-2015) were assessed. All strains were subjected to MS, and those
not accurately identified by this technique were genomically verified.
Among the outcomes of this study, we highlight: 1) MS fingerprinting
resulted in the consistent identification of 90.1% of strains; 2) B.
pseudobassiana is reported for the first time in the South American
continent, in a subtropical region and from two insect orders not yet
associated with this taxon; and 3) four taxa were recognized, with the
great majority of strains belonging to B. bassiana s.str. (93.4%),
followed by B. caledonica (2.5%), B. pseudobassiana (2.5%) and B.
amorpha (1.6%). We also showed that some strains previously ascribed to
B. brongniartii are misidentifications. Our previous work with the
complex Metarhizium anisopliae confirmed a considerable diversity in
Brazil. Surprisingly, the biodiversity of Beauveria shown in the present
study was comparatively low. The geographic origins of strains used in
our study was biased towards biomes with intense human interventions,
such as the Cerrado. Future surveys on more conserved, less
environmentally disturbed biomes, such as Caatinga, Pampa, Pantanal, and
Amazon are necessary for a more comprehensive picture on the Brazilian
diversity within the Beauveria and related genera.
